title: Restoring force - does the equation result in SHM

content.question: An object of mass <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> is free to move along a curved track with negligible friction. The shape of the track results in the following equation that expresses Newton’s second law for the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-coordinate of the object’s motion: <math alttext="M times the second derivative of x with respect to t squared equals beta times, open parenthesis, x minus x sub 0, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mi>β</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>, where <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> is time, <math alttext="beta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>β</mi></math> is a positive constant with appropriate units, and <math alttext="x sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> is a position where the object’s acceleration is zero in the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-direction. If the object is released from rest on the track at an initial position other than <math alttext="x sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, will its <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-coordinate exhibit simple harmonic motion? What reasoning or evidence supports the claim?

choices.label: Yes. The net force is a linear function of position.
Yes. There is an equilibrium position where the net force is zero.
No. The net force is not zero at <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>.
No. The net force is not in the opposite direction from the object’s displacement from equilibrium.

content.answer: No. The net force is not in the opposite direction from the object’s displacement from equilibrium.
